Notes:
Financial Modelling is required.  See below for summary of the scenarios required. 

Modelling
In all scenarios-
-	Living needs are $120k pa (includes rent)
-	He is currently unsure on where he�ll live, he currently expects to live 1/3rd in Holland, Thailand, Australia. 

Current
-	Assume PPT super is paid out in lump sum cash to Ray, then he retains all other assets as is.   
-	No home purchase

Scenario 1
-	No home purchase,
-	PPT super is converted to a pension for Ray. 
-	Ray would like to purchase another Commercial Property ($500k) Assume yield of 7% and QPP growth rates for property.
-	Rebalance of all monies (all investments in the fact find) into a 50/50 portfolio in his name. 
-	
Scenario 2
-	In 12 months he purchases a new property/ies for $2m including costs. No rent from this property. 
-	PPT super is converted to a pension
-	Ray would like to purchase another Commercial Property ($500k) Assume yield of 7%. Use QPP growth rate for property.
-	Remaining assets invested into a 50/50 portfolio in his name (~$3.8m)
-	Maintain livings expenses at $120k (even though he doesn�t� need to rent), but please include the value of the new $2m home and its growth in the modelling results.

Investments_Cash_Notes:
Following the sale of direct shares, your bank account will have a balance of $29,736. We recommend you use these funds as follows:
* Use $990 for estate planning purposes
* Use $1,000 to commence a regular savings plan
* Use $1,000 to commence a regular gearing plan
* Leave the remainder ($26,746) to fund new car planned expense in February 2015
* Direct a surplus of $1,500 per fortnight ($15,000pa) to build funds for a new car and rebuild bank account to $10,000 for cash reserve (desired amount)

When Tania is off work for 12 months following the birth of her child we recommend you cease directing surplus cashflow to your bank account (balance should be $10,000 by this time).

When Tania is back at work and the 1st child is in child care we recommend you direct surplus cash flow of $450 per month ($5,400pa) to your bank account to help fund some renovations and planned expenses.
Investments_Managed_Funds_Notes:
We recommend you commence a Savings Plan Portfolio with $1,000 from your bank account via an MLC MasterKey Investment Service Fundamentals and invest these funds into the MLC Cash fund, we then recommend you commence a regular savings plan of $500 per month $6,000pa) and invest these funds into the MLC H2 - Income Portfolio. This is based on time-frame for planned expenses.

Following the repayment of the GE Money Personal Loan, we recommend you increase the Regular Savings Plan to $1,000 per month ($12,000pa). Cease this when Tania is off work.

Your cashflow will be around $5,415 per annum less for the 12 months off work following the birth of your first child as a  result of the decreased FTB A. Withdraw funds from your Savings Plan Portfolio if any additional funds are needed.

When Tania is back at work and the 1st child is in child care we recommend you recommence your regular savings plan of $1,000 per month ($12,000pa). 

When Tania is back at work and the 2 children are in child care we recommend you cease directing your surplus cashflow to your bank account as there will be no surplus cash flow.

Gearing_New_gearing_Notes:
We recommend you take out a $1,000 NAB Margin Loan and invest this into a Geared Portfolio. We recommend you commence an installment gearing strategy where $500 per month is drawn from the loan and matched with own funds. 

We recommend you commence a Geared Portfolio with $2,000 ($1,000 of own money and $1,000 from loan) via MLC MasterKey Investment Service Fundamentals.

We specifically recommend you invest $1,000 into the MLC Cash Fund and $1,000 into the MLC IncomeBuilder fund. This is based on long timeframe for investment. We then recommend you commence a Regular Gearing Plan of $1,000 per month ($500 of own money and $500 drawn from loan) to build sufficient wealth to repay debt. These funds will be invested into the MLC IncomeBuilder fund.

This will allow you to accumulate sufficient wealth to have your Home Loan repaid in approximately 10 years.

They are wishing to proceed with the purchase of an investment property using the LRBA strategy of an SMSF.

After reviewing their current super and Insurance arrangements the situation is 

?	Lynette needs to keep her policy at Asgard in place as she had a major operation a couple of years ago on her Kidney and is now unlikely to get cover elsewhere.  This allows for $5,000 rollover from Asgard to  an SMSF
?	Dean has a employer scheme that is transferring to a My super account  by 2017. The employer, VISY, currently covers the cost of Insurance and so this needs t be kept in place.
o	The action is to ensure that the new mysuper account can accept current Insurance. A spoke to OnePath (Brad 16 Jan @ 3.18pm advisor line) and they advised a rollover to ANZ Smart Choice can be completed over the phone by the client and retains the Insurance.  Takes about 20 Days. This would create an account with a balance of $170,000 plus any contributions.
o	Ongoing contributions are $57626 @9.5% as base Income is low then addition of 77to be assessed if can be paid to SMSF and not affect any Insurance. This to occur once property in place to access improved tax benefits. So initial position is that the Ongoing Contributions to remain with employer.
o	
?	Cost will be $ 11,000 in Govt fees, Bank Costs of $2500, Advice and set up fees of $5200 total of $18,700.

Strategy approach and actions ? 

1.	Rollover $165,000 of Dean?s account.
2.	Rollover $5,000 from Lynette Perpetual account to SMSF
3.	SMSF will have $170,000 and borrow 65% of $420,000 or $273,000, leaving 23,000 in the fund
4.	Costs are covered from the $23000.  There will be accumulated interest and a further $10,000 available if needed as the property will take 12 months to complete.

a.	Annual audit cost of $440, 
b.	Accounting fees of $1500 
c.	Rental income on property of $330 per week, $17160 per annum.

Super_Defined_ben_vs_accum_Notes: Joseph's DB balance is being rolled into the BHP Retention Fund.  (VALUE $1,252,201) This balance is predominantly untaxed monies, so should not be combined with other non-concessional contributions to be recommended as outlined below.
Super_Non_Concess_Cont_Notes: Both Doris and Joe are to be recommended to contribute $180k each to super now ie pre 30 June 2015, with a further $540k each to super immediately post 30 June 2015.  They will then each contribute up to a further $540k to super in the 2019 financial year.
Super_Rollover_and_invest_Notes:
Clients are to rollover their various existing retail super funds (4 in total) to a new personal super plan to be opened as follows:
Doris - MLC Fundamentals Personal Super
Joseph - MLC Fundamentals Personal Super Plan 
Monies are to be invested 100% in the Horizon Series. 

NOTE - OVERALL INVESTMENT STRATEGY IS TO BE 30% GROWTH ASSETS.  NON SUPER SHARES AND ALL OTHER ASSETS EXCLUDING PROPERTIES ARE TO BE INCLUDED IN THIS 30% EXPOSURE.  THEREFORE, SUPER MAY END UP INVESTED IN HORIZON 3 or 4 WITH OTHER MONIES OUTSIDE OF SUPER INVESTED 100% in CASH/FIXED INTEREST.  YOU ARE TO ASCERTAIN SPECIFIC PERCENTAGES FOLLOWING YOUR MODELLING.
Super_Self_emp_conc_cont_Notes: SOA is to recommend both clients contribute up to $35k each to super via personal super contributions, in order to cap their personal MTR at $18,201 where possible and on an ongoing basis.  As it is possible Joe may return to work in the future, he is not to make any concessional contributions until close to 30 June each year when he can be certain he would not have received any employer super support or will meet the 10% rule.  Of course, for 2015 Joseph is not eligible to arrange a concessional contribution as he has received employer super support.
Pension_New_and_invest_Notes:
Subject to your modelling analysis confirming this, Joseph is NOT to convert his BHP Super to an ABP within the BHP personal division until he attains age 60, as the tax payable on the pension would exceed the benefits even after allowing for earnings tax of 15% within super (please correct me if I am wrong here).  We can provide a PDS if you require any details in this regard re fees and other features.
Joseph to convert the full balance of his amalgamated MLC Fundamentals Super (less minimum balance to remain open) to an ABP ie MLC Fundamentals Pension Fund (Horizon Series)
Doris to convert the full balance of her amalgamated MLC Fundamentals Super (less minimum balance to remain open) to an ABP ie MLC Fundamentals Pension Fund (Horizon Series)

Minimum pension payments only ever to be paid from MLC pensions as balance will be largely tax free component.  Any surplus monies to be paid from non super monies first, then BHP Pension when established post age 60.

Pension_New_and_invest_Notes: Using $375,000 (100%) in MLC Wrap Super Series 2 start a T2R pension now, drawing a fixed pension from the cash option of $22,000 pa or $1833 per month. This amount will provide Lesley with almost an identical income to her current after tax income when allowing for our recommended salary sacrifice contributions.
Pension1_Notes: Glen, what are the underlying investments for the TTR?

Alternative_Strategies:
Invest the $300,000 available funds outside super was considered but not recommended as using a T2R pension will save considerable tax as the fund itself pays no tax on earnings and 80% of the pension will be funded from the tax free component and hence not taxable either. All income and capital gains would be taxable if we invest the funds outside super. Downside of T2R pension is preservation until Lesley retires sometime after her 60th birthday in April 2016 but as we are setting aside a significant sum for a cash reserve and any short term expenses we are comfortable with this arrangement.
Buying another investment property was also considered but not advisable due to fully taxable status, illiquid nature of property, lack of diversification (Lesley already has one which she is considering selling soon), and the very high prices of residential property in Australia by world standards.

Notes:
This is the first one I have done through you guys so please give me feedback if I have provided too little or too much or if there are any questions at all.

The adviser on this one can be Greg Stevens.

The client is an existing client who basically has funds with us at the moment in a CFS retail fund (details attached).

He wants advice on moving the funds into his SMSF and putting the funds into comparable investments to what he has with same risk profile so that he can consolidate into his SMSF and also reduce some management fees.

Our investment service is such that we review each quarter and have the ability or scope to reduce or increase weightings/asset allocations in the portfolio if we see opportunities or risks so I would like this noted in there so it can be an ROA in the future.

We have addressed going to pension and the client is a bit hesitant so we would like it addressed as an alternative strategy so it can also be addressed at a later date or even at the time of presenting.

The clients have all estate planning under control and don't need advice here.  Same with insurance - we have advised them previously.

I have attached what we are recommending for investments - we will be setting up a Commsec Adviser Services account to trade through - brokerage is $33 or .011%.  We will also be setting up an Australian Money Market Cash Broking account for Macquarie Cash account and TDs (no commissions ect)

Trustees of SMSF are Helen John and Timothy Vickers.

Investment Strategy (SMSF) will be reviewed before proceeding with the advice and amendments will be made if necessary (waiting on accountant).

We will also coordinate with accountant for Binding Death Nomination paperwork for his wife Helen.

Pension paperwork also coordinated if that option is proceeded with.

Is the above self-employed income for each of them or combined?  
What are the living expenses?
Are you receiving ongoing commission for the Aviva insurance and if so what is the %?

Continue to pay off loan on Stanthorpe property as quickly as possible as well as margin loan as both these assets will be retained long term and into retirement. (Stanthorpe property is rented to Penny's mum.)

At retirement Warren and Penny will either sell Bribie Island property if staying in Toowoomba or else if moving to Bribie Island sell their Toowoomba home to clear the debt. If the latter occurs they may realise a surplus of $100,000 or more as the Toowomba home value exceeds the loan on Bribie Island. These surplus funds would be put towards paying off any residual debt on Stanthorpe or the margin loan firstly and if any left over towards general retirement funding. Warren and Penny are undecided about retiring to Bribie Island? If they decide to stay in Toowoomba they will also likely downsize their home also freeing up additional capital.

Risk Profiles: 

Client Specific Risk Profile � discussions

We reconfirmed Trevor and Kaye�s risk profile. We had last done profile questionnaires last year.  They�d indicated somewhere between 50-50 Cautious and 30-70 Moderate profiles for them.

We discussed that the stronger performance from some of the Growth assets has pushed them up to their current 30-70 benchmark and if nothing else we need to take some profit to go back to the overweight Defensive position that we had been targeting nearer 40-60.

Trevor reconfirmed that he had been a balanced 30-70 client for all of his time with us and that we could move to the 30-70 benchmark level or continue our tactical overweight.  Trevor was quite ambivalent about it, and he understands the need to take some profit and reallocate.  However, Trevor doesn�t want to adopt an excessively conservative asset allocation position and so was inclined to adopt the less Defensive posture on 30-70 Moderate for he and Kaye rather than make a shift to 50-50 Cautious.

To help determine the correct balance of investment risk for you, we have:

�	Asked you to complete a Risk Profile assessment. We have taken the results of this assessment and using a risk assessment model, on this basis we determined that your ideal balance at this time is to aim for a target mixture of approximately ##% Defensive investment assets and ##% Growth investment assets.
�	Explained that Defensive investment assets are there to provide stability of your investment capital and so are chiefly focussed upon the return of your capital in the short to medium term, rather than the return on it.

Conversely, we have also explained that Growth investment assets are there to provide growth of your investment capital and so are primarily focussed upon the long-term return on your capital, rather than the return of it. So they are far less stable.
�	Referred you to the MLC Strategic Overlay & Portfolio Design report for details of how the mixture of Defensive and Growth investment assets referred to above should be comprised.

The MLC Strategic Overlay & Portfolio Design report provides the basis for determining the mix of different investment types, so that your portfolio includes both the right combination of Defensive and Growth investment assets to meet your Risk Profile and also an appropriate mix of types of investments to anticipate the Economic and Financial Markets outlook (known as an Asset Allocation).

The MLC Strategic Overlay & Portfolio Design report is updated quarterly and is available via our web site at:
http://www.gpadviser.com.au/north-adelaide-brosnan/category/news/
�	Finally, we have also taken into account other factors that arose in our discussions and research of your situation.

?	You would like to reduce your existing debt as soon as possible and have asked ?can your existing loans be paid off any quicker? 
?	 We have calculated how quickly it would take to repay your loans once we have restructured your assets so your SMSF can purchase your Business Real Property and the funds from the sale used to reduce your debts. For example if we have your business real property re-valued (as valuation has not been carried out for some years) and say it is now valued at $200,000.00 we can have the SMSF purchase property at the current market value and these funds can be used to reduce your existing debts to say $50,000.00. 
?	Than using your current repayments of $657.00 per Fortnight paid off your remaining loan balance of $50,000.00 dollars, @ your current interest rate of 4.95%, it would take approximately 3 years and two month to repay this debt 
?	Restructuring and paying down the remaining loan whilst maintain your current repayments at $657.00 Per F/N should enable you to save approximately $197,633.00 in interest repayments and 26 years 10 months off the loan repayment time.
Debt2_Advice:
Separate section at the end of all advice stating Issues to Consider:

Should you decide to restructure loans from outside the super area to inside may have these additional benefits:
o	Improve before tax cash flow
o	Less profit left in the business to be taxed
o	Lease payments are being paid directly into your SMSF, which ensures your building (property) is paying its way.
o	Additional money is being paid into your super fund to help your future retirement plans (Lower Tax Environment)
o	The money contributed ensures greater Tax Advantage amounts are added to your SMSF.
o	The Loan is able to be serviced from the lease payments being made, surplus cash flow and yearly contributions being made. 
The additional amounts contributed to the SMSF due to the restructure will ensure additional capital to produce more Tax free income in retirement after age 60.
Gearing_Gearing_into_super_Notes:
Separate section at the end of all advice stating Issues to Consider:

?	Steve & Cath, as your (SMSF) investment/assets grow you may have sufficient assets to be utilised to purchase property, provided you are able to meet all the listed requirements below and a lending institution will provide finance up to at least 60% of the current proposed purchase price.
?	To purchase a property inside your SMSF with borrowings a Non - Recourse Loan structure with an appropriate lender will be required. We will also need to establish a Corporate Security Trustee (Custodian - Bear Trust) to hold the asset (Business Real Property) on trust for the SMSF until the loan is repaid and the mortgage discharged. (Include the diagram for a Typical Borrowing Structure).    
?	You will need to consider the following steps  when setting up a Non-Recourse loan to purchase Business Real Property
o	Obtain Valuation Report for the Property prior to proceeding with the purchase.
o	Obtain a written arms-length rental appraisal for the property prior to agreeing to the sale and ensure the appropriate commercial lease is in place prior to the contracts being drawn up. 
o	Obtain approval for Non-Recourse Loan at a maximum of 60% of the property value; say $330,000 if the Property is valued at $550,000.
o	Sell the property to the NEW SMSF Entity to: 
-	Reduce the Number of loans
-	Clear personal debts
-	Allow the property to be owned by the SMSF
-	Rental/Lease payments will be made to the SMSF.
-	Any Lease and annual contributions could be adequate to pay off the loan within the agreed term and help pay out the balance of the loan years earlier than current projections.
-	Limit the liability to the business real property only via the SMSF.  
?	Ensure the property to be purchased is an asset that can be purchased under the SIS legislation.
?	Before any documents are signed and any deposit is paid, ensure advice has been sought from suitably qualified practitioner in the jurisdiction where the asset (Property) is located, to ensure the correct procedures are followed and no unnecessary stamp duty liability arises.
?	Ensure the contract for exchange must be in the name of the Corporate Security Trustee for the Bare Trust.
?	Once the contract for sale has been received confirm via your solicitor that the property being purchased is on the ONE title, the correct address is listed and the land Lot and Portfolio Numbers are of the land proposed to be purchased are listed accurately on the contract 
?	Once all documents have been received organise finance using a suitably qualified Mortgage broker or your current Bank.
?	Before paying a deposit or exchanging contracts ensure finance has been approved and Loan Agreement documents have been received, reviewed and executed as required.
?	Ensure the SMSF pays the deposit for the property, because if it is paid by another party, our understanding of current legislation is, it is treated as a contribution and not able to be refunded. 
?	You will need to ensure a commercial lease is drawn up reflecting current market value of lease payments that would reflect the value of the Business Real Property proposed. 
?	The lease is to be between the SMSF say Norvill Super Fund and the Tenant of the property SJ & CL Norvill Builders.  
?	Property Lease payments can be made to the fund
?	The property purchased by the SMSF must be revalued at market value each year. Independent third party valuations should be obtained at least every three years, with valuations from all other years being supplied by the Property Manager or Trustee Declaration.  
?	Trustee responsibilities for LRBA
?	The money may be able to be invested in a more diversified way to produce similar returns with a much lower Investment risk.
SMSF ? PROPERTY SALES AND POSSIBLE OPTIONS
?	The Trust Deed should reflect SMSF Borrowings so the SMSF can borrow to purchase the property.  (Conditions apply)
?	Our understanding is that the assets held in your Property Trust will be classified as Business Real Property and as Business real property can be traded with a related party if required. If this type of transaction is executed correctly, it can translate into significant net financial benefits that can greatly increase your net retirement income.
?	Under current legislation, if the Property inside the SMSF is sold when in pension phase, no Capital Gains Tax is payable.     
?	Direct Australian Shares with Franking Credits can also ensure the net SMSF benefits are maximised by helping to reduce the effective SMSF tax rate and/or be instrumental in the fund claiming tax back from the ATO.
SMSF_Est_SMSF_and_invest_Notes: Using MLC WRAP Investments for the Portfolio and NBA CMA for the Cash account.  MULTIPORT are the Administrators for the SMSF.
SMSF_Notes:
?	Setup a SMSF to provide the appropriate Superannuation structure to purchase and hold/own your Business Real Property. 
?	Set up SMSF using Corporate Trustees.
?	Your existing super balances combined total $601,338 at 16th March 2015, which is sufficient for us to recommend you look at setting up your own SMSF.
?	  Steve & Cath you are both currently earning $57,400.00 pa and $57,435 pa respectively. 
?	You both own additional properties that could be sold and the proceeds contributed to super if required. 
?	You also own a property at 40 Cook St used for your Building business this would be classed as Business Real Property which could be sold/transferred to your recommended SMSF.
?	Steve, we recommend rolling over your existing Super funds to the new recommended SMSF (Multiport /MLC Wrap Investment Fund Portfolio) in line with your identified risk profile of a Balanced  investor
o	Summit/North Super Fund approx. total value of $368,477.00  
?	Cath, we recommend rolling over your existing Super funds to the new recommended SMSF (Multiport/MLC Wrap Investment Fund Portfolio) in line with your identified risk profile of a Balanced investor.
o	Summit/North Super Fund approx. total value of $232,862.00  
?	Steve and Cath you also own a property (8A Denne Street Tamworth NSW 2340) that you may consider selling.  You could contribute the sale profits to Super (after CGT has been paid) as this will allow you to increase funds within your SMSF to possible purchase another investment property as part of the SMSF assets.
?	We recommend selling your Business Real Property at 40 Cook Street Tamworth to the SMSF for the current estimated market value of say $200,000. This would allow funds to be drawn out of your SMSF as payment for the property and this money could be used to reduce your debts.
?	The Business Real Property is to be leased back to your trading entity of SJ & CL Norvill at the current expected rental rate (Say $14,000.00 pa.) for a property of its type and location. 
?	The valuation and rental rate should be calculated by a suitably qualified property Valuer and/or Real estate agent. 
?	Use funds to reduce existing loans by approx. $200,000 (outstanding).
?	Before proceeding with our recommendations you as individuals read the ATO publication about the responsibilities you will undertake as Trustee of your own SMSF and that you are happy to take on Trustee se responsibilities before proceeding. 
CONTRIBUTIONS ?Non Concessional, Concessional & SGC
?	Make ongoing non-concessional & concessional contributions to the maximum allowed.
?	Ensure your future Super Contributions are directed and paid into the new recommended SMSF.
?	By continuing to contribute to your SMSF will allow sufficient funds inside the SMSF to increase your retirement savings and should allow the purchase another investment property as part of the SMFS assets.
HAVING YOUR OWN SMSF WILL GIVE YOU:
?	Greater control over the Investment decisions within the SMSF
?	Allow you to purchase direct property and/or direct shares within the fund.
?	The SMSF is individually taxed, allowing for more efficient individual investment strategies to help minimise the overall fund effective tax rate.
?	The SMSF structure can be utilised to purchase direct property and/or borrow additional funds if required to accomplish the property purchase.
?	Direct property depreciation schedule will help reduce the effective tax paid within the fund.
?	Direct Share imputation credits will also help reduce the effective tax paid within the fund.  (Direct Australian Shares with Franking Credits can also ensure the net SMSF benefits are maximised by helping to reduce the effective SMSF tax rate and/or be instrumental in the fund claiming tax back from the ATO)
?	The ability, as Trustees of your own SMSF to formulate your own Investment Strategy with the ability to select Advanced Planning?s model Investment portfolio, as part of your overall investment strategy.
?	The fund can accept all types of contributions including, Salary Sacrifice, Employer, Member and Award, etc.
?	The SMSF can borrow to purchase the investment property if required. (Conditions apply)
?	If a property is Business real property it can be traded with a related party if required. If this type of transaction is executed correctly, it can translate into significant net financial benefits that can greatly increase your net retirement income.

You are happy with your current levels of cover and have requested to base our advice on these amounts.

Life & TPD ? INSIDE SUPER
Steve
?	We recommend applying for $484,137.00 of Death Cover and $37,439.00 of TPD Cover via AMP ? These amounts of cover are currently held within your existing AMP Summit/North Super Insurance Policy, however, in order to free up cash flow and for the SMSF to pay/own the premiums this cover will need to be cancelled and replaced, and by applying for this cover ?Like for Like? (Level Premiums) with AMP you should not have to undergo any further medicals or underwriting. 
?	This will also lock in this level of cover listed above to prevent the insured amount reducing with your age, as is currently the case for your Insurance held via the Summit/North Super fund.   
?	If you were to apply for this cover under any other company you would be required to undergo medicals and full underwriting and this was a specific request that you did not wish to have to go through. 
?	The proposed policy is to be owned and paid by the SMSF.

(Level Premiums) with AMP you should not have to undergo any further medicals or underwriting.

Steve & Cath
?	Maintain your current levels of insurance cover (as requested) ? Life, Critical Illness/Trauma Cover & IP Cover as this cover is to provide for family protection outside of Superannuation.  Steve, currently still has personal debts to clear, and you require your income protection cover to continue.  Steve, maintaining existing Critical Illness/Trauma cover to clear all or part of your debts is still important to you.
INSURANCE NOTES
?	We strongly advise that should net asset levels change and/or you borrow money inside the SMSF you reconsider reviewing your levels of insurance cover. We recommend you are insured for at least the nett level of Debt you will continue to have after any restructure of your borrowing level.   
?	Should you sell one of your properties now and clear this debt, you may choose to lower the amount of insurance cover you have in line with the debt reduction and your families? ongoing financial needs.
?	Once the actual reduced level of Insurance cover is decided after reducing or paying out your debts, we can recalculate your insurance premiums to determine the actual Insurance premium savings we are able to achieve. 
?	The insurance policies applied for can be locked into ?Level? premiums if you expect that the current level of debt will continue long term greater than 10 years.
Tax_Notes:
?	Income earned inside superannuation is taxed at a maximum rate of 15% whereas earnings outside of super are added to your assessable income and taxed at your marginal tax rate. 
?	Once your reach age 60 and retire permanently from the workforce, based on current legislation the earnings on your superannuation balance and the income paid from your superannuation fund  could be tax free. 
?	There are limits and rules to how much you can contribute to super. Exceeding these limits can incur penalty rate of tax. We can show you how you can contribute these proceeds to super without impacting on these limits.

CO1_Notes:
Steve would like to be fully retired by 1/7/19.
Vicki may look to continue to work for a period once her IP claim ceases. Would like to keep working until age 64 but notes this may be unlikely.
CO2_Notes: Annual living expenses $60,000 per annum, reducing by 25% after age 75. Steve and Vicki would like to understand capital required to provide the desired level of income in retirement. For the purpose of projections assume capital can be spent over the retirement period.
CO3_Notes: Expect to spend $10,000 per annum in addition on travel for the first 10 years of retirement.
CO4_Notes: Expect to spend $40,000 on a new car in 2019 once Steve retires.
Client_Objectives:
Clients would like to understand where, as a result of our recommendations, we expect them to be by 1/7/19 relative to required capital requirements as per their retirement lifestyle preferences. 

Another significant goal is full repayment of any outstanding debt by the time Steve is retired. Please note that this is addressed partially by super split to V for FY 15/16 then lump sum withdrawal in Aug 2016 to pay off some debt. Current outstanding is $215,000 with payments of $800 per FN. Assume fortnightly debt payment continues post the lump sum next year until Steve retires. Assume LS drawing is made to pay off balance in 2019. 

Please note that Vicki may receive a bequest of $200k at some point which would have a significant impact on retirement capital. In reality this would clear the debt but we will assume a conservative position on this and note that this may bridge any capital shortfall. 

Assume average portfolio return for any projections of 7% to age 75 and 5% thereafter, net of costs. 

How much do they require vs how much are they likely to have post strategies and debt payment. 

During the pre retirement phase assume no additional savings capacity as the balance of income net of salary sacrifice will be needed for lifestyle and renovation expenses. 

Vicki has 1 more year of IP claim, this is pretty much funding remaining renovation expenses. In a years time they will be living off 1 income. 

Post FY16 no super split to Vicki. 

We will add a note re potential Centrelink, but this will be a general comment only, we can adjust this once we have the draft. 

As noted, we have provided the investment recs based on $790k for Steve and $50k for Vicki assuming FY15 super split has been actioned. 

Our recommendation is likely to be MLC Wrap for both with fee aggregation and availability of preferred investment options. Note could use Australian Super member direct however not preferred option given limited access to preferred 'point of difference' investment managers. 

We will add notes re maintaining insurances. 

*Note that we have received Non approved exemption for Slater & Gordon - SGH.

Alternative_Strategies:
The only major issue of debate after numerous meetings is whether or not to use the MLC Masterkey - Capital Protected component over the Multi-Indexed Balance Portfolio. Nalin, is concerned that he will not be returning to work therefore he doesn't want to take too many risks with his retirement assets. Agreed to place 50% in the MLC Capital Protected Fund and 50% in a high growth Netwealth Super Fund.
The alternative would be not to use the 'Capital Protected' feature but manage the risk by choosing the investments to suit his investment risk profile. This would save the client 1.65% p.a. Capital Protection Fee over 10 years.

CO1_Notes: Brett needs some assistance in structuring his finances to provide a predictable income now and for many years.  He owns his home outright today and wishes to live a comfortable but not extravagent lifestyle. Brett needs assistance making appropriate investments to fund this lifestyle and minimise costs and taxes paid where possible to assist in meeting living costs.
CO2_Notes: He is happy living in KANWAL NSW (Central Coast region) as many older friends are there now, but will consider downsizing over time where needed to fund living costs over time.  $37,000 annual income is desired and occasional overseas trip of $10K possible but not a high priority at this time
CO3_Notes: We have determined the existing BT Super account is high cost and does noit have Capital Protection available.  We have located a lower cost vehicle being MLC MKSF/MKPF that reduces the ongoing costs, and enables Capital protection to be implemented, and make appropriate asset allocation investments to achieve goals stated.
Client_Objectives:
Although Brett scored a "Capital Stable" investor Profile with 30% Growth asset allocation, he understands the need high yielding investments and likes benefits of franking credits being received ongoing.  

For Long Term Investments such as Super, Brett is happy with a 50/50 "Conservative Growth" profile without Capital Protection.  Alternatively manitaining a 65-70% Growth Allocation could be acceptable providing the "Capital Protection" feature is implemented providing downside risk protection.  This was discussed and Brett prefers this approach with his new Super investments

We have broadly discussed the cost of Capital Protection for MLC Index Plus Balanced fund being approx 1% of FUM with a 20 year horizon, ability to add capital over time being implemented.  Detailed calcuilations to be provided to quantify exactly, but this is very close to mark for SOA purposes
Super_Non_Concess_Cont_Notes: Brett currently has $500,000 within a Bank Account currently following the passing of parents, earning maximum 3% interest. By placing these funds into Super environment under NCC basis, a better return may be achieved and still fully accessible once Brett retires - technically now as age 56 and DOB in 1959
Super_Rollover_and_invest_Notes: Rollover existing BT Super to MLC MKSF as fees are much lower and availability of Capital Protection of high importance to Brett.  Retain small balance within BT Super account to fund needed insurances  (Leave $7,000 in BT)
Pension_New_and_invest_Notes: Commence a TTR Pension now by utilising $550K of funds with MLCMKSF account and placing in MKPF account paying $37,000 annually - which is his defined living costs with generous estimations provided for each living cost item shown in Fact Find docs.
Ins_Super_Life_Notes: Maintain existing Life cover within BT Super until client decides no longer needed.  Maintain small balance to fund ongoing, say $7,000 in total funding both Life+TPD premiums
Ins_Super_TPD_Notes: Maintain existing Life cover within BT Super until client decides no longer needed.
Insurance1_Advice: He Has $60,000 of Life and TPD Cover costing $88.40 per month
EP_Power_of_Attorney_Notes: Define and Implement ASAP
EP_Super_beneficiaries_Notes: Define and Implement ASAP
EP_Wills_Notes: Define and Implement ASAP
Alternative_Strategies:
Buying a new investment property with $500K funds in Bank account.  Not yet implemented as Brett has not yet located new property and not familiar with managing Investment properties.  Could be considered over time, but not appropriate now, and low yields within Direct Property of major concern, as is limited growth evident in Central Coast area that is most familliar to Brett currently

Existing BT Super investments are too aggressive currently - with 70% Growth allocation worrying.  Brett does not want this risk maintained and see this as highly risky currently especially after several years of good performances evident.

Maintaing the 3% interest upon $500K High Interest savings account was considered, but the returns here do not support the income in retirement desired here with capital erosion evident if maintained Long Term, and not keeping pace with Inflation and after income tax paid
Insurance_Ongoing: Approx 25% of premiums paid ($1080 x 25% = $270 p.a.)
Insurance_Ongoing_How: debited to Existing Super Fund (no changes)

Super_Rollover_and_invest_Notes:
Carrie - Full rollover to new MLC Masterkey super fundamentals 
RBA
1)	More investment options
2)	Better insurance offering 
3)	MLC offers level premiums inside their super which is not available from their existing super fund.
4)	Life cover buyback is not available from their existing super fund.
5)	30% discount on IP premium for linking multiple policies 
6)	MLC Masterkey pays contribution tax annually ensuring that invested funds are working harder for longer.
7)	By investing in sector specific funds we believe that we can improve your superannuation portfolio's investment returns compared to the poor returns your portfolio has generated to date 
8)	Although overall the new fund costs more than your current fund, the increased costs arise as a result of a more actively managed underlying investment portfolio with a higher exposure to growth assets. We feel that benefits associated with the recommended fund outweigh the additional costs.

Risk profile 85/15

Ins_Pers_Critical_Illness_Notes:
Replace current Colonial VitalCare policy with a new TAL Critical Illness policy.

TAL policy provides more flexible policy definitions for a greater number of events.

Specifically Meningococcal disease, small bowel transplants included in Major Organ transplant, minor Heart Attack definition, Motor Neurone disease, Muscular Dystrophy, Lupus, not requiring 6 weeks for Major Head trauma definition, Parkinsons Disease, Severe Diabetes and more.  

If upgrades are made to the policy, then this will apply to your product and there is no need to change or reapply.

Review Notes

Discussion Topics

    Review of Plan Objectives

    Gai stopped sal sac last Christmas as I had raised at previous meeting she was contributing too much and she needed to reduce it.  She stopped it altogether as cash flow was tight with Stephen not working.  We talked about re-starting again and that Stephen?s TTR pension can supplement her reduced take home pay.
    Planning to travel for 12 months in 2016.  They?re going to rent out their home for the year.  They?re expecting rental income of approx. $750 - $800 pw.  Plus supplement travelling costs from accessing Stephen?s super via a pension.
    Stephen is not actively looking for work given their travelling plans.  He?s being doing odd jobs and expects to get another $5k for the next 6 months.  Given his low level of income I recommended that he starts a TTR so that Gai can re-start sal sac and also earnings is tax free.  After tax offsets I calculated that there should be no tax payable on drawing the min. pension.

    Summary of Cash Flow

    Cash flow is presently being met from Gai?s net salary.  Stephen?s income has helped in the last couple of months so that more of Gai?s salary is saved.

    Timeframes (client modelling)

    Travelling all of 2016
    Return to full time employment from 2017

    Portfolio Performance

    We went over the ups and downs of market volatility and stressed the importance of investing for the long term and not being too focussed on market noise (e.g. Grexit)

    Portfolio Risk

    I pointed out that they have different target asset allocations for their various super accounts.  Plum super is 30G/70D, FSS is 70G/30D and their 2 MLC Wrap Super is approx. 57G/43D. 
        Gai said she didn?t know which option she was invested in and had picked the default.  I said that she can select a more defensive option if she wanted to.  However, she is happy to keep the same. 
        Stephen switched to a more conservative option with his Plum Super given that his not working and wanted to protect more of his capita.
        Both confirmed that they were happy to retain the MLC Wrap Super asset allocation as they are now.

    Basis of Investment Advice

    Commence TTR (Stephen) for both MLC and Plum Super accounts
    Sal sac $2,150 pf (Gai) ? calculations on file

    Details of Investment Advice

    No investment changes.

    Taxation Planning

    Gai to sal sac $2,150 pf up until end of 2015.

    Superannuation

    $35k CC cap

    Legislative Changes

    N/A

    Debt Funding

    N/A

    Insurance Assessment

    Maintaining health insurance
    Maintaining general insurance on home and car
    Gai has in-build insurance cover within her FSS account.

    Estate Planning

    Wills are in place but no EPOA.  Recommended that they need to arrange this before they go travelling.

    Service Provided / Feedback

    Gai felt that we haven?t been contacting them enough. For instance she could of sal sac earlier this year.  I noted that I had spoken to Stephen a few times to get a job update.  Nevertheless, I said they can contact us anytime and don?t need to wait until we contact them.  Particularly when there is a change in their circumstances then they should just call.

    Fees & Associations

    Discussed fees and types of fees
        Platform fees
        Investment fees
        Adviser ongoing fees (1.1%)
    Client understood the fees ? no issues.
    Provided FDS and opt-in signed

    Helping Others

    Not asked

    The Year Ahead / Other Items

    Next Meeting in Nov as their review was pushed back from May.  This will also allow us time to make any changes before travelling.

Income_Notes: DSP of $659.30pfn
Client_Objectives: Goal is to sort out a system to ensure that Stephens disability support pension will not be affected by the proceeds of the estate, and for investments to protected from outsiders due to Stephens vulnerability.
Investments_Shares_Notes: Various Shares $300,000
Estate_Planning_Notes: Refer to notes below.
Alternative_Strategies: Not quite sure what this comes under as it is more aligned with social security, and setting up a special disability trust to ensure that his benefit is not affected with the estate of his late father.
Notes:
As a result of the estate of Stephens late father, Stephen will be entitled to a house, shares and cash. Stephen is currently receiving a disability support pension, His brother graham has enduring power of attorney over his brother now that their father has passed away.
Looking to set up a Special Disability Trust for Stephen, and transferring all shares and cash into the trust, which would be exempt from the asset test for Disability support pension purposes. 
Stephen will inherit the house that he currently lives in, valued at $410,000.
Stephen will be entitled to 30% of the shares and cash in the estate file, please ignore the property side of things, as that has been worked out and will not affect the trust. 
As a result of this, Stephen should be entitled to approximately $134,837 in cash and $321,490 in shares. .
With the Special Disability Trust, Stephen can transfer up to $500,000, to avoid having the excess classed as 'deprived assets. The combined amount of cash and shares will be less than the $500,000 cap
I have included a breakdown of what Stephen will receive as a result of the estate (which he will receive 30% of). The family only want one off advice for this, with no ongoing relationship. 
The shares will be managed by the public trustee, however protected in the trust itself and thus exempt from DSP asset testing. 
More than happy to discuss this further, as I have never had an SOA written for a special disability trust,but wanting to ensure that I meet all licensee standards.

Investment_Notes:
Looking to set up a discretionary trust for Madison Wallace, with her and her father being the directors, and herself, father and mother being the appointers. This should be set up as a single trustee, as opposed to a corporate trustee in the first instance as the cheapest option, however can be changed later down the track.
This will meet her goal of providing protection on her investment from any further partner. As she will be the sole beneficiary initially, then she will stream all income to herself from a tax perspective, however can make tax effective distributions in the future. 
Madison has received $55,000 from a payout from a car accident and would like to invest the entire amount (less fees for myself and establishment of the trust).

CO1_Notes: Stopping the Account Based Pension will help build up retirement savings
Super_Rollover_and_invest_Notes:
Terry's Account Based Pension was created by a previous adviser and during the GFC. The ABP was invested into a Term Deposit as the main investment and is now set to mature on the 10th of September.

We are recommending that he not recommence the Term Deposit. Terry does not need the income as he has sufficient Cash reserves, so we are recommending that he rollover the proceeds of his Challenger Account Based Pension, into his existing Colonial First State FirstChoice W/Sale Super fund. The details are attached in the CFS Fee and Asset allocation doc.
Alternative_Strategies:
Keep Account Based Pension

The strategy is to keep building his Superannuation assets till he reaches age 63, when is the approximate time that Terry wants to finish work. Continuing an Account Based Pension would be against that strategy

Keeping the funds invested in Term Deposits

We don't believe that Cash and Term Deposits are going to assist Terry meet his retirement income goals over the long term and the recent downturn in the market provide an ideal opportunity to invest a portion into growth assets

Tax_Salary_packaging_Notes:
PAYMENTS ON RETIREMENT 
(David)
We have run the numbers on David retiring end of this calendar year (31/12/15) vs Early next FY (July 2016) and the taxation consequences of Leave entitlements paid at those dates.

In short, the average tax rate on the Annual & LSL (of which almost all will be subject to MTRs) would be:
-   42% approx. ($61,500) if David retires 31/12/2015 vs 
- 39% approx. ($57,000) if David receives them in July 2016

Though there would likely be some income tax saving, David would have forgone 6 months worth of CSS Pension benefits which equate to approx. $33,500. 

Therefore we see no significant benefit in delaying retirement simply to receive Leave entitlements in a new FY.   

Please assume David is therefore paid out his AL & LSL in a cash lump sum on retirement at 31/12/2015.
Gross $146,416 after tax is estimated to be $85,000.
We recommend adding these funds ($85k) to super. as NCC.

(Heather)
Heather's net leave entitlement of circa $3,000 should be added to bank account to top up cash reserve.
Alternative_Strategies: Shelter additional monies in super for Heather to target part Age Pension - not recommended for a number of reasons including; (a) as you are in a very strong financial position which allows self-funding (b) you have not expressed a desire to target part Pension as a high priority and in preference to other wealth building / tax minimisation strategies (c) moving additional monies into super for Heather would result in more funds being subject to 15% fund tax on earnings as opposed to the 0% tax rate on earnings within super Pension phase for David.
Initial_Fee_How: Applied $3,025 to each MLC Super account on set up
Ongoing_Advice_Fee_How: Applied $2,200pa to each MLC Super account

Debt2_Advice:
Should you decide to restructure loans from outside the super area to inside may have these additional benefits:
o	Improve before tax cash flow
o	Less profit left in the business to be taxed
o	Lease payments are being paid directly into your SMSF, which ensures your building (property) is paying its way.
o	Additional money is being paid into your super fund to help your future retirement plans (Lower Tax Environment)
o	The money contributed ensures greater Tax Advantage amounts are added to your SMSF.
o	The Loan is able to be serviced from the lease payments being made, surplus cash flow and yearly contributions being made. 
The additional amounts contributed to the SMSF due to the restructure will ensure additional capital to produce more Tax free income in retirement after age 60.

CONTRIBUTIONS �Non Concessional, Concessional & SGC
�	Make ongoing non-concessional & concessional contributions to the maximum allowed if surplus funds allow.

HAVING YOUR OWN SMSF WILL GIVE YOU:
�	Greater control over the Investment decisions within the SMSF
�	Allow you to purchase direct property and/or direct shares within the fund.
�	The SMSF is individually taxed, allowing for more efficient individual investment strategies to help minimise the overall fund effective tax rate.
�	The SMSF structure can be utilised to purchase direct property and/or borrow additional funds if required to accomplish the property purchase.
�	Direct property depreciation schedule will help reduce the effective tax paid within the fund.
�	Direct Share imputation credits will also help reduce the effective tax paid within the fund.  (Direct Australian Shares with Franking Credits can also ensure the net SMSF benefits are maximised by helping to reduce the effective SMSF tax rate and/or be instrumental in the fund claiming tax back from the ATO)
�	The ability, as Trustees of your own SMSF to formulate your own Investment Strategy with the ability to select Advanced Planning�s model Investment portfolio, as part of your overall investment strategy.
�	The fund can accept all types of contributions including, Salary Sacrifice, Employer, Member and Award, etc.
�	The SMSF can borrow to purchase the investment property if required. (Conditions apply)
�	If a property is Business real property it can be traded with a related party if required. If this type of transaction is executed correctly, it can translate into significant net financial benefits that can greatly increase your net retirement income.

�	Mark & Lesley, as your (SMSF) investment/assets grow you may have sufficient assets to be utilised to purchase property, provided you are able to meet all the listed requirements below and a lending institution will provide finance up to at least 60% of the current proposed purchase price.
�	To purchase a property inside your SMSF with borrowings a Non - Recourse Loan structure with an appropriate lender will be required. We will also need to establish a Corporate Security Trustee (Custodian - Bare Trust) to hold the asset (Business Real Property) on trust for the SMSF until the loan is repaid and the mortgage discharged. (Include the diagram for a Typical Borrowing Structure).    
�	You will need to consider the following steps  when setting up a Non-Recourse loan to purchase Business Real Property
o	Obtain Valuation Report for the Property prior to proceeding with the purchase.
o	Obtain a written arms-length rental appraisal for the property prior to agreeing to the sale and ensure the appropriate commercial lease is in place prior to the contracts being drawn up. 
o	Obtain approval for Non-Recourse Loan at a maximum of 60% of the property value; say $......... if the Property is valued at $............
o	Sell the property to the NEW SMSF Entity to: 
-	Reduce the Number of loans
-	Clear personal debts
-	Allow the property to be owned by the SMSF
-	Rental/Lease payments will be made to the SMSF.
-	Any Lease and annual contributions could be adequate to pay off the loan within the agreed term and help pay out the balance of the loan years earlier than current projections.
-	Limit the liability to the business real property only via the SMSF.  
�	Ensure the property to be purchased is an asset that can be purchased under the SIS legislation.
�	Before any documents are signed and any deposit is paid, ensure advice has been sought from suitably qualified practitioner in the jurisdiction where the asset (Property) is located, to ensure the correct procedures are followed and no unnecessary stamp duty liability arises.
�	Ensure the contract for exchange must be in the name of the Corporate Security Trustee for the Bare Trust.
�	Once the contract for sale has been received confirm via your solicitor that the property being purchased is on the ONE title, the correct address is listed and the land Lot and Portfolio Numbers are of the land proposed to be purchased are listed accurately on the contract 
�	Once all documents have been received organise finance using a suitably qualified Mortgage broker or your current Bank.
�	Before paying a deposit or exchanging contracts ensure finance has been approved and Loan Agreement documents have been received, reviewed and executed as required.
�	Ensure the SMSF pays the deposit for the property, because if it is paid by another party, our understanding of current legislation is, it is treated as a contribution and not able to be refunded. 
�	You will need to ensure a commercial lease is drawn up reflecting current market value of lease payments that would reflect the value of the Business Real Property proposed. 
�	The lease is to be between the SMSF say MR & LT Cotter Super Fund and the Tenant of the property A1 Windscreen.
�	Property Lease payments can be made to the fund
�	The property purchased by the SMSF must be revalued at market value each year. Independent third party valuations should be obtained at least every three years, with valuations from all other years being supplied by the Property Manager or Trustee Declaration.  
�	Trustee responsibilities for LRBA
�	The money may be able to be invested in a more diversified way to produce similar returns with a much lower Investment risk.
SMSF � PROPERTY SALES AND POSSIBLE OPTIONS
�	The Trust Deed should reflect SMSF Borrowings so the SMSF can borrow to purchase the property.  (Conditions apply)
�	Our understanding is that the assets held in your Property Trust will be classified as Business Real Property and as Business real property can be traded with a related party if required. If this type of transaction is executed correctly, it can translate into significant net financial benefits that can greatly increase your net retirement income.
�	Under current legislation, if the Property inside the SMSF is sold when in pension phase, no Capital Gains Tax is payable.     
�	Direct Australian Shares with Franking Credits can also ensure the net SMSF benefits are maximised by helping to reduce the effective SMSF tax rate and/or be instrumental in the fund claiming tax back from the ATO.

Dr K should look to make NCC of $180,000 each FY that he works up to Age 75 � 2020/2021 for him.  He should look to employ the same strategy of funding the NCC from larger drawdowns from the P1 interest which is 77.87% Taxable.  

After taking the legislated minimum pension payment from his largely Tax Free Pension, he should rollback this to accumulation, pick up the NCC made, and then recommence a Pension.

Indeed, given that the P1 interest is 77.87% Taxable, this should be the Pension that will be the go to source of all NCC contributions � both for Dr k and Mrs K.

He should look to make the CC contributions, but again, only after making the NCC and Pension refreshment t. The CC can then be cashed out in July of the following FY. 

Dr  needs to be mindful that any contributions needs to be done within a month of him turning 75.

Mrs K 
Mr K should next look to make a NCC of $180,000 in 2018/2019 and every FY that she works up to Age 75 � 2025/2026 for her.  She should look to employ the same strategy of funding the NCC from larger drawdowns from Dr K P1 interest which is 77.87% Taxable and the from her P1 Interest which is 57.50 taxable.

However, we will look to revisit where the NCC come from as there will become a time when Mrs K P1 Pension will be the best place to source funds for NCC strategies.

She should look to make the CC contributions, but again,( if making an NCC) only after making the NCC and Pension refreshment t. The CC can then be cashed out in July of the following FY. 

Para planning, please illustrate the potential tax savings (with SMSF proceeds going to Estate) using the above strategies assuming contributions are mad till Age 75 for both Dr K and Mrs K.  

Please note, the SMSF has no Reserves available to pay anti-detriment payments and the lumpy nature of the assets prevents rollover to commercial provider.

Centrelink_Age_Pension_Notes:
Brian is reaching age pension age. We recommending a withdrawal from Brian's Account Based Pension and increase Margaret's Superannuation fund.

We are recommending that Brian withdraw $75,000 to invest into Margaret's Super. This will not provide him with the full Age Pension, however as the lower threshold changes on the 1st of January 2017, this will then provide them with the full age at that time. This will then allow him to keep more funds in his Account Based pension to draw their required income.

The withdrawal is to be made from:

$15,000 from Perpetual Global
$15,000 from CFS Index Global Hedged
$45,000 from 6 month TD (there are no break fees)

Pension_New_and_invest_Notes:
Establish a new Macquarie Wrap Super Manager Account to consolidate existing MLC and State Plus super funds.  Once consolidation is complete and the $180,000 personal contribution received rollover 100% of funds (less the $2,500 that is required to stay in the Super Manager Cash Account as the minimum requirement) to a Transition to Retirement Pension within a linked Macquarie Wrap Pension Manager account. Please note Geoff will need to maintain $2,500 in the Super Manager Cash Account to meet the minimum requirement.   

Recommendation is to take the minimum pension payments paid monthly.

Key reasons:
- Boost tax free income
- Zero tax payable on earnings for the funds in pension mode as compared to 15% tax on funds in accumulation.

?	This will see the 15% Tax owed on the Untaxed Portion removed.  
?	She should then cash out the funds and then recontribute the funds as an NCC ? this will see her entire account made up of tax free components.
Super2_Notes:
Their assets consist of:
?	A GESB West State Accumulation account of $300,157.  This has an untaxed element of $132,387 and a tax free element of  $167,770

?	A GESB Gold State Defined Benefit of $263,786 ? this has an untaxed element of $214,303 and a tax free element of  $49,482

GESB West State and Gold State are Constitutionally Protected Funds.   See attached Tax Fact sheet. The Gold State is a defined benefit that is now capped but it will go up with CPI plus 2%.  We went through this but she wants to roll it now ? I had suggested that given her conservative nature she could be guaranteed of a certain return better than current cash rates ? she directed that the fund be moved to retirement option as she was keen to remove tax on it should she pass away.
If either the West State or Gold State are cashed out they are subject t to an extra tax (Medicare levy) that is avoided if rolled into super first and then cashed out.
Pension2_Notes:
?	She should then roll to Pension (GESB Retirement Fund) draw difference each year to meet her $60,000 spending needs.
?	She should have Roy as a reversionary beneficiary
?	The above needs to be completed prior to her turning 65 ? she has the full $540,000 available to her but of done after Age 65 she must meet a work test.

Shares

* Repay investment loan in full from share proceeds																
* Repay mortgage in full to free up cash flow																
* Maintain LOC to continue to have funds available 																
* Client has a novated car lease, at the end of the lease the balloon payment is $20,240 (Feb 2016). Client wishes to extend his lease for another 12 months. 	

Planned Expenses / Savings Plan										
* Invest $89,817 into H2 ($1,000 in cash)										
* RSP of $3,600 per month ($43,200pa) into H2 to fund Car and Caravan at Retirement (RSP to cease at retirement)										
* Fund annual holidays from savings plan until retirement										
										
				
Superannuation																	
*Maintain Sal Sac as already on highest tax bracket																	
*For Ray - Portability rollover Mine Wealth and Wellbeing - to maintain insurances and Portability rollover of south32 - as employers choice of super. (MKSF 1) - into H5 as per risk profile																	
*For Michelle - full rollover of Colonial, portable of NGS to maintain insurances (MKSF 1) - into H5 as per risk profile																	
*Withdraw URNP in Mine Wealth Wellbeing and NCC into a separate tax-free super fund for Ray (MKSF 2)																	
*Spouse contribution into Michelle's MLC Super, monthly max $3,000pa, this will enable him to get an offset, and for Michelle to be able to grow her super.																	
																	
Personal Insurance																	
* IP cover is currently $67,600pa, very underinsured, however, will be able to retire on leave payments if is unable to work. Therefore maintain IP, no additional insurances needed																	
* One year until retirement, Ray discussed potentially using his leave (close to two years) to extend retirement comfortably over another 3 years - therefore, minimum CI to give family access to Best Dcotors																	
* Michelle may not have loadings on a CI policy, therefore put in place minimum for her also. If she gets loadings due to joint/bone conditions do not proceed																	
* Maintain insurances in current super due to relatively low premiums and proximitiy to retirement.																	
																	
Other																	
*Has about 2 years of LSL, client will not be able to retire in 1 years' time and will need to take his LSL and then retire i.e. age 62																	
*Alternativeally should he receive a redundancy in 6-12 months of approx. $500K will be able to comfortably retire effective immediately - do projection to show this. 																	
																	
Estate Planning																	
* Standard will w/EPOA and EPOG - Heard McEwan																	
																	
Future Strategies																	
* When Ray is age 60, start a TTR of the taxble super (MKSF 1) and take out 10% each year (as a lump sum) and NCC every year back into the tax-free super (MKSF 2) - for approx 2 years, until retirement - age 62.																	
* Once Michelle reaches preservation age (age 56 in 2 years) , withdraw up to the $185K taxable cap and recontribute into a separate tax-free super (MKSF 2) - base on current level of super. 																	
* When Ray retires at age 62, withdraw up to cap ($540K) and recontribute into Michelle's tax free Super (MKSF 2) depending on growth, this should leave Ray with just a tax-free super.																	
* Show tax savings for recontribution strategy (based on current super levels) and tax savings for rolling into a pension (TTR prior to retirement).																	
* Excess contributions will count towards NCC cap - please take into consideration when doing the recontribution strategy i.e. $22,348pa																	
																	
Projections																	
* Assume income level is maintained for the 2 years whilst on leave. Retirement projection to go for 3 years. 																	
* Please do current, expenses can be drawn from LOC if required.

Investments_Managed_Funds_Notes:
INVESTMENT CHANGES (MLC Wrap pension): 
REBALANCING

1. Sell down ALL  investments within Suzy's MLC Wrap Pension account
2. Maintain $100,000 as cash within the MLC Wrap Cash Account to provide liquidity and to protect this portion of the pension capital
3. Invest the balance of the pension account (all other monies) into MLC Wholesale Horizon 4 Balanced Portfolio (MLC0260AU)

Reasons / Benefits:
- Added diversification (reduce risk and smooth returns)
- Benefit from MLC's professional management and experience in managing Fund of Funds portfolios which have a SAA in line with your risk tolerance
- Following recent discussions with you we have determined that a direct (listed securities) component of the portfolio is no longer suitable or required (enhance ease of management)

Suzy is currently receiving $306pf Age Pension + $78pf supplements = $9,984 per annum total. 

1. Provide estimate of Age Pension payable now
2. Provide estimate / modelling of Age Pension going forward (i.e. incl. changes to assets test and taper from 1 Jan 2017).

PLEASE NOTE:
Suzy has a Life Interest in her principal residence and therefore we understand she is treated as a 'Single Homeowner' for Centrelink purposes.
Alternative_Strategies:
Maintain a direct (listed) component to Pension portfolio - due to a range of factors including current portfolio size, our discussions regarding whether or not higher control and direct investment remains a priority of your's, and the expected ease of management and smoother return profile of a Fund of Funds approach we have not recommended retaining direct shares within you pension fund. 

Reduce MLC Wrap Pension draw down to extend longevity of pension capital - you have reviewed your budget and have confirmed that your lifestyle need is $55,000pa (all inclusive) . Have advised her to contribute $180,000 as a non-concessional contribution into a MLC masterkey fundamentals account which I will set up for her, and invest in the horizon 3 fund to coincide with her risk profile. 
Based on her current salary, she also wanted to start salary sacrificing, have advised that $100 per fortnight would be achievable for her.

Lump_Sum_Expenditure_Notes:
Planned Expsenses											
	* Fund planned expenses via available redraw.

Debt_Refinancing_Notes:
Debt															
	* Refinance Home loan. Fix a portion of the loan for 5 years making interest only repayments and maintain the remaining balance variable and make P&I repayments.														
	* Refiance Investment Property Loan to a new fixed rate loan for 5 years and Make IO repayments on investment property loan.														
	* Refinance Car loans to home loan.														
	* Increase mortgage to a limit of $375,500 (allocated an extra $80,000 so they can redraw to fund a year off and kitchen. Also added an extra $1,917 for refinance and break costs).
Super_Notes:
Super					
	* Cancel Kemp's REST Super. Rollover in full.				
	* Keep FSS and Hesta. Assumed they don't have choice of super.				
	* Rollover FSS and Hesta under portability.				
	* Invest into MKSF H6 for both.
Insurance1_Advice:
Insurances																
	* Keep FSS insurance and keep Hesta Life. Cancel Hesta IP.															
	* Apply for Life, CI and IP (indemnity policy) for Lance for MLC.															
	* Apply for Life, IP & CI for Casey through MLC.															
	* Cancel HESTA IP as its an indemnity and she plans on taking 12 months maternity therefore if she goes back part-time or sick or injured after going back she won't receive the full benefit.															
	* Keep Real Insurance for 12 months.															
	* Review Lance's MLC IP in 12 months to see if he can increase due to business income.
